questions.text: Which is not true regarding the basis of functional divisions of liver
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref.: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery 25/e p 1081 https:// clinicalgate . Com / liver-2/ SEGMENTAL ANATOMY: Couinaud classification • It divides the liver into eight functionally independent segments. • Each segment has its own vascular inflow, outflow and biliary drainage • In the centre of each segment there is a branch of the portal vein, hepatic artery and bile duct. • In the periphery of each segment there is vascular outflow through the hepatic veins. • Right hepatic vein divides the right lobe into anterior and posterior segments. • Middle hepatic vein divides the liver into right and left lobes (or right and left hemi liver). This plane runs from the inferior vena cava to the gallbladder fossa. • The Falciform ligament divides the left lobe into a medial-segment IV and a lateral part - segment II and III. • The portal vein divides the liver into upper and lower segments. • The left and right portal veins branch superiorly and inferiorly to project into the centre of ach segment. 3 Major fissures : Hepatic veins Minor fissures : 3 A) Right Portal vein fissure B) Left Portal Vein fissure C) Fissure of Ganz

questions.text: What is false about Meckel’s Diverticulitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Present in 3 % of the population Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 25/e p 1158 Meckel's diverticulum is rare and accounts for only 2% of the general population. An equal incidence is found in men and women. Meckel's diverticulitis is one of the recognized complications of the condition and is clinically indistinguishable from appendicitis, except that the pain and tenderness typically localized at the periumbilical region. Progress of the diverticulitis may lead to perforation and peritonitis

questions.text: A patients underwent thyroidectomy for Hyperthyroidism . Two days later he presented with features of thyroid Storm . What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Inadequate preoperative preparation Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 25/e , p 791 THYROID STORM • This is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. • It occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy and is now extremely rare. • Very rarely, a thyrotoxic patient presents in a crisis and this may follow an unrelated operation. • Symptomatic and supportive treatment is for dehydration, hyperpyrexia and restlessness. • This requires the administration of intravenous fluids, cooling the patient with ice packs, administration of oxygen, diuretics for cardiac failure, digoxin for uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, sedation and intravenous hydrocortisone. • Specific treatment is by carbimazole 10–20 mg 6-hourly, Lugol’s iodine 10 drops 8-hourly by mouth or sodium iodide 1 g i.v. Propranolol intravenously (1–2 mg) or orally (40 mg 6-hourly) will block ¬-adrenergic effects.

questions.text: A 60 years old chronic smoker presented with progressive jaundice, pruritis and clay colored stools for 1 month. History of waxing and waning episodes was present. A CT scan revealed dilated main pancreatic duct and common bile duct. What is the likely diagnosis?

Their natural history is distinctly more favourable compared with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. Ampullary carcinomas are relatively small when diagnosed, which may account for their better prognosis

questions.text: During laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, a tack was accidently placed below and lateral to the iliopubic tract Postoperatively the patient complained of pain and soreness in the thigh. This is due to the involvement of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral cutaneous N. of Thigh Ref: Schwartz: Principles of surgery 8/e Chapter 36: Dr. P.Bhatia: Laparoscopic Hernia Repair p4.7 Chronic pain, defined as pain present three months after surgery, is common after all forms of surgery. It is less common and less severe after laparoscopic surgery. Different types of pain have been described but the most severe is neuralgic pain due to nerve irritation. This may be the result of nerve injury at the time of operation or chronic irritation of nerves by suture material or mesh. Careful identification and protection of all three nerves passing along the inguinal canal reduces the incidence of neuralgic pain. This type of pain is also very uncommon after laparoscopic surgery which is performed at a deeper level away from the nerves. Some contribution to chronic pain may be due to the mesh which can become embedded in a dense collagenous reaction with shrinkage. This causes tissue tension and rigidity.

choices.text: Check for response and call help

questions.text: An unresponsive patient has been brought to you by the police. What is the first thing you will do?
questions.solution: C. check for response and call help. Cardiac arrest Cardiac arrest occurs when the heart stops pumping in a regular rhythm. In this situation, early defibrillation is the key to returning the victim's heart back to a normal rhythm. When a defibrillator is not readily available, a rescuer or bystander should keep the blood flowing by performing chest compressions and rescue breaths at an age-appropriate rate until it is. Respiratory Arrest Respiratory arrest is when there is no measurable breathing in a victim. It tends to occur in conjunction with cardiac arrest, but this is not always the case. Respiratory arrest is the most common indication of BLS in infants and toddlers. The most critical factor in restoring breathing in the victim is to provide high quality rescue breaths. Drowning In cases of drowning, rescuers should provide CPR as soon as an unresponsive victim is removed from the water. In particular, rescue breathing is important in this situation. A lone rescuer is typically advised to give CPR for a short time before leaving the victim to call emergency medical services. Since the primary cause of cardiac arrest and death in drowning and choking victims is hypoxemia, it is recommended to start with rescue breaths before proceeding to chest compressions (if pulseless). If the victim presents in a shockable rhythm, early defibrillation is still recommended. Ref: BLS/ACLS Guidelines: https:// www.resus.org.uk/resuscittion-guidelines/adult-advanced-life-support/

choices.text: Complete obstruction of common bile duct

questions.text: In a patient with obstructive jaundice, what is the possible explanation for a bilirubin level of 40mg/dL?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malignant obstruction A bilirubin level of 40 mg/dL is an extraordinarily high value in the context of obstructive jaundice. Normal bilirubin levels are typically below 1.2 mg/dL. While any severe obstruction can raise bilirubin, levels reaching 20 mg/dL or higher, and especially as high as 40 mg/dL, are highly suggestive of a malignant (cancerous) cause. Malignant obstructions (e.g., pancreatic head cancer, cholangiocarcinoma, ampullary carcinoma) tend to cause a complete, rigid, and unrelenting blockage of the common bile duct. This results in maximum impedance to bile flow and thus the highest possible bilirubin accumulation, as the obstruction is typically progressive and unrelieved. Incorrect Options: Option (B) Complete obstruction of common bile duct Explanation: While a complete obstruction is necessary to achieve such high bilirubin levels, this option describes the nature of the obstruction rather than its cause. Both benign (e.g., a very large, impacted gallstone) and malignant causes can lead to complete obstruction. However, malignant obstructions are far more likely to produce such persistently and profoundly high bilirubin levels because they are often more severe, less amenable to spontaneous resolution, and can progressively worsen the blockage. Therefore, while true that it's a complete obstruction, "malignant obstruction" is a more specific and statistically probable etiology for a bilirubin level of 40 mg/dL. Option (C) Renal failure Explanation: Renal failure (kidney failure) primarily affects the excretion of waste products by the kidneys. Bilirubin is processed by the liver and primarily excreted in bile via the gastrointestinal tract, with only a very small amount excreted by the kidneys. Therefore, isolated renal failure would not cause a bilirubin level of 40 mg/dL. While patients with severe multi-organ failure (which could include both liver and kidney failure) might have high bilirubin, renal failure itself is not the primary explanation for such a high bilirubin level in the context of obstructive jaundice. Option (D) Liver failure Explanation: Liver failure means the liver cells themselves are damaged and unable to conjugate (process) or excrete bilirubin effectively. In severe liver failure, bilirubin levels can indeed become very high. However, the question specifies "obstructive jaundice," indicating that the primary problem is a blockage of bile flow, not a primary failure of the liver cells to produce or metabolize bile. While prolonged, severe obstructive jaundice can secondarily lead to liver damage over time, a bilirubin level of 40 mg/dL primarily suggests an extremely severe obstruction, with malignancy being the most common cause of such a profound and unremitting blockage. If it were primary liver failure, other signs of hepatic dysfunction (e.g., coagulopathy, encephalopathy) would be more prominent, and the jaundice would not necessarily be classified as purely "obstructive."

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal and a subnormal free T4. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The thyroid function test (TFT) results show: TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone) much higher than normal: This indicates that the pituitary gland is working overtime, trying to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more hormones. Free T4 (Thyroxine) subnormal: This indicates that the thyroid gland itself is not producing enough thyroid hormone. This specific combination of a high TSH and a low Free T4 is the hallmark of primary hypothyroidism. In this condition, the thyroid gland is the primary problem; it is underactive and cannot produce sufficient thyroid hormones. The pituitary gland then compensates by increasing TSH secretion in an attempt to "kick-start" the failing thyroid. Incorrect Options: Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Explanation: Hyperthyroidism, or an overactive thyroid, would present with the opposite laboratory findings: a low TSH (because the pituitary gland reduces stimulation to an overactive thyroid) and a high Free T4 (due to excessive thyroid hormone production). Option C. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Explanation: Subclinical hypothyroidism is characterized by a high TSH (indicating mild thyroid underactivity) but a normal Free T4. The thyroid is just beginning to become underactive, and the pituitary is working harder to maintain T4 levels within the normal range. The "subnormal" Free T4 in the question rules out subclinical hypothyroidism. Option D. Secondary hypothyroidism: Explanation: Secondary hypothyroidism is a rare condition where the problem lies with the pituitary gland itself, which fails to produce enough TSH. This would result in a low TSH (due to pituitary dysfunction) and consequently a low Free T4 (because the thyroid isn't receiving enough stimulation). The "much higher than normal" TSH in the question contradicts this diagnosis.

questions.text: A-30-years old female was admitted to casualty with history of head trauma in a RTA. Her Eye opens to pain, moans, localises towards the pain on left-hand and away from the pain or right hand, both the legs in extended posture. Calculate her GCS

questions.text: A 45-years old female with history of painless breast lump measuring 6.2x4.5 cm in left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed Ductal Carcinoma in situ. She underwent surgery with resection of all tumor tissue with adequate margins and postoperative HPE showed with DCIS with high grade necrosis with 4 mm clearance on margins. Which of the following is needed?
questions.solution: (B) Adjuvant radiotherapy In this case, the patient has undergone surgery and had all tumor tissue removed with sufficient margins, but the histopathological examination revealed high-grade necrosis and 4 mm of margin clearance. In such cases, adjuvant radiotherapy is required to reduce the risk of local recurrence. Adjuvant chemotherapy is not indicated in Pure DCIS without invasion. Van Nys Prognostic Index for DCIS: A) Age B) Type of DCIS C) Size of DCIS D) Margin status E) Presence of Microcalcifcations.

questions.text: A 56-years-old came to casualty with history of massive hemoptypsis. His routine investigation chest X-ray was normal. Which of the following you will not do to prevent hemoptypsis?
questions.solution: d) Procoagulant drugs Pro coagulant drugs do not play any definite role in management of MASSIVE hemoptysis. Massive hemoptysis is defined as >500-600ml blood loss in 24 hrs However occlusion of proximal airway occurs with only 150ml of clotted blood. Mortatlity is due to drowning or suffocation (due to obstruction of airway by clotted bloodrather than exsanguination) Digital X ray is the 1st line investigation. MDCT is IOC Digital substraction angiography is the gold standard. Bronchial arteries are the mc source. Conservative management with ANGIOEMBOLOIZATION is the 1st line . Surgery is reserved for non respondents Ref. Schwartz Principle of Surgery 10th edition; pg. 661-664

questions.text: What is the percentage that an USG can detect Lymph node metastases in a patient with breast cancer clinically negative lymph nodes?
questions.solution: (d) 50-60% Ref. Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 10th edition; pg. 527 and 531, Factual question nvasive breast cancer is one of the most common malignancies in women. The most common sites of metastasis are the axillary lymph nodes (LNs). Moreover, the number of metastasis-positive LNs is considered the most powerful predictor of patient prognosis. Despite screening tests, approximately 8% to 30% of newly diagnosed breast cancers are at an advanced stage, with extensive LN metastasis. Although the development of multimodal treatments has improved survival outcomes in breast cancer patients, outcomes remain unsatisfactory in patients with multiple axillary LN metastases. Older treatment regimens resulted in 5-year overall survival (OS) rates of approximately 40%, more recent advanced treatment modalities have resulted in 5-year OS rates of 66% and 81%. Despite these improvements, however, factors prognostic of survival in patients with extensive LN metastasis remain unclear.

questions.text: ‘Fr in Foleys denotes:
questions.solution: a, it is outer circumference The tube has two separated channels, or lumens, running down its length. One lumen, open at both ends, drains urine into a collection bag. The other has a valve on the outside end and connects to a balloon at the inside tip. The balloon is inflated with sterile water when it lies inside the bladder to stop it from slipping out. Manufacturers usually produce Foley catheters using silicone or coated natural latex. Coatings include polytetrafluoroethylene, hydrogel, or a silicon elastomer – the different properties of these surface coatings determine whether the catheter is suitable for 28-day or 3-month indwelling duration.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding superior mesenteric artery syndrome?
questions.solution: A • Superior mesenteric artery arises from abdominal aorta at the level of L1. It makes an angle of 40 to 65 degrees with aorta. • 3rd part of duodenum and fat is present in between SMA and aorta • When this pad of fat is lost, the angle between SMA and aorta becomes less. At angles <25 degree , symptoms of SMA syndrome starts occurring • SMA syndrome / wilke’s syndrome presents as compression of third part of duodenum • Other causes of SMA syndrome are : high insertion of duodenum non ligament of treitz, low origin of SMA. • Treatment : initially conservative, surgery: dudodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, strong’s sugery ( division of ligament of treitz)

questions.text: The given image shows methylene blue being injected in the peritumoral region. Which of the given procedure is being performed?
questions.solution: A Sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node draining the tumour. Sentinel lymp node biopsy is done in a clinically node -ve tumour patient undergoing breast conservative surgery. Techniques: • Blue dye technique ( shown in the above image) : methylene blue or isosulphan blue dye is injected in subcutaneous plane around the tumour. The first lymph node which takes up this dye is biopsied. • Radionucleotide technique: Tc99 tagged sulphur colloid injected in periareolar region. Sentinel LN is identified by gamma camera. • Sentimag technique: ferric oxide compound is injected near to the tumour and LN is identified by magnetic scanner. If Sentinel lymph node comes +ve for tumour cells , then axillary clearance is done ( minimum of 10 LN removed)

questions.text: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to-
An intubated patient with eye opening to pain with abnormal flexion. What is the GCS score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) E2VNTM3 The patient's GCS score is E2VNTM3. This is determined by assessing each component based on the patient's presentation: Eye (E) Response: E2 The patient exhibits "eye opening to pain." According to the GCS criteria, eye opening in response to a pain stimulus is assigned a score of 2. Verbal (V) Response: VNT The patient is "intubated." This means a true verbal response cannot be assessed, as their airway is compromised by the tube. In such cases, the verbal component is marked as "Not Testable" (NT) or "T" (for tube), indicating that the physical limitation prevents evaluation. Therefore, VNT is the appropriate designation. Motor (M) Response: M3 The patient displays "abnormal flexion." This refers to decorticate posturing, a specific motor response to pain characterized by internal rotation of the shoulder, flexion of the forearm and wrist with a clenched fist, and leg extension with plantarflexion of the foot. According to GCS motor criteria, this response is assigned a score of 3. Incorrect Options: B. E2VTM3: While VTM3 is also a common and acceptable way to denote "verbal not testable" for an intubated patient (where 'T' stands for tube), VNT explicitly spells out "Not Testable" which aligns perfectly with the inability to assess. Both convey the same information about the verbal component. However, given the option set, and the clear "Not Testable" implication, A is a highly precise representation. C. E2V1M3: Assigning a V1 score ("No verbal response") to an intubated patient is incorrect. A V1 implies the patient could speak but chose not to or was unable to produce any sound, which isn't the case here. The verbal component cannot be assessed at all due to the physical presence of the endotracheal tube, making it "not testable." D. E2VTM4: This option is incorrect because the motor response of "abnormal flexion" (decorticate posturing) corresponds to an M3 score, not M4. An M4 response indicates "Withdrawal from pain," where the patient pulls away from the painful stimulus but without abnormal posturing.

questions.text: True about Splenunculi:
questions.solution: A Splenenculi are accessory splenic tissue occurring due to failure of primodial splenic buds in dorsal mesogastrium. Most common site for occurrence of splenenculiis : Hilum > tail of pancres. Other sites are gastrosplenic ligaments, omentum etc. it contains well formed capsule and are often multiple ( 2 to 6). They contain more amount of white pulp tissue than red pulp. If splenectomy is being donr for hemtological disorders, this tissue must be removed alon with the spleen. If splenectomy is being done after trauma, this tissue must be preserved This must be differentiated from a condition called splenosis. This is an acquired condition which occurs after trauma in which splenic tissue is auto transplanted in different sites. This tissue lacks well formed capsule

questions.text: Most common site of GIST is
questions.solution: C GIST occursmostcommonly in stomach (50%) A gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is a type of tumor that occurs in the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly in the stomach or small intestine. The tumors are thought to grow from specialized cells found in the gastrointestinal tract called interstitial cells of Cajal (ICCs) or precursors to these cells. GISTs may present with trouble swallowing, gastrointestinal bleeding, or metastases (mainly in the liver). Intestinal obstruction is rare, due to the tumor's outward pattern of growth. Often, there is a history of vague abdominal pain or discomfort, and the tumor has become rather large by time the diagnosis is made

questions.text: If a patient comes with acute abdomen, which of the following test(s) can be done in supine position?
questions.solution: ABCD Explanation: The psoas sign, also known as Cope's psoas test or Obraztsova's sign, is a medical sign that indicates irritation to the iliopsoas group of hip flexors in the abdomen, and consequently indicates that the inflamed appendix is retrocaecal in orientation Rovsing sign: In supine position, palpation of the left lower quadrant of a person's abdomen increases the pain felt in the right lower quadrant, the patient is said to have a positive Rovsing's sign and may have appendicitis. The obturator sign or Cope's obturator test is an indicator of irritation to the obturator internus muscle. The technique for detecting the obturator sign, called the obturator test, is carried out on each leg in succession. The patient lies on her/his back with the hip and knee both flexed at ninety degrees. The examiner holds the patient's ankle with one hand and knee with the other hand. The examiner internally rotates the hip by moving the patient's ankle away from the patient's body while allowing the knee to move only inward. This is flexion and internal rotation of the hip. In the clinical context, it is performed when acute appendicitis is suspected Carnett's test is a simple clinical test in which abdominal tenderness is evaluated in supine position while the patient tenses the abdominal muscles. It is useful for differentiating abdominal wall pain from intra-abdominal pain Ballance sign: A dull percussion resonance sound heard on the right flank of a patient lying in the left decubitus position, an indication ofa ruptured spleen. The sound is caused by an accumulation of liquid blood on the right side and coagulated blood on theleft.

In 3rd degree, hyperemia, edema and blisters/vesicles appear In 4th degree, gangrene and autoamputation can happen. Treatment includes rapid rewarming, analgesia, Aspirin, Topical antibiotics etc

questions.text: After long segment ileal resection with competent and sparedileocaecal valve, which of the following is/are seen?
questions.solution: DE Ref: Schwartz 10th Ed/1171 Explanation: Maintaining the integrity of ileocecal valve prevents diarrhea as well as bacterial overgrowth. As per Schwartz 10th Ed, “an intact ileocecal valve is believed to be associated with decreased malabsorption. The ileocecal valve delays transit of chyme from the small intestine into the colon, thereby prolonging the contact time between nutrients and thesmall-intestinal absorptive mucosa. Short bowel syndrome has been arbitrarily defined as the presence of less than 200 cm of residual small bowel in adultpatients Resection of less than 50% of the small intestine is generally well tolerated. However, clinically significant malabsorption occurs when greater than 50% to 80% of the small intestine has been resected.Steatorrhea, cholelithiasis, oxalate kidney stones and nutritional deficiencies are all known manifestations.

questions.text: True regarding phylloides tumour of breast is/are?
questions.solution: AE Ref: Schwartz 10th Ed/555 Explanation: Phylloides tumour/Cystosarcomaphylloides Rare, mostly benign tumour seen in the female breast. It is the most common non-epithelial neoplasm of the breast 58% are benign, 12% are borderline malignant and 20% are frankly malignant Most common in females aged 40-50 years Firm, palpable mass with a bosselated surface is common presentation. Rapidly grow in size and overlying skin may be tense and shiny with dilated veins No LN involvement is seen FNAC not sufficient, require open excisional biopsy for making the diagnosis Surgical treatment involves local excision in small tumours and mastectomy in larger lesions, with no need for axillary LN dissection.

questions.text: The abdominal mass in pyloric stenosis in a new born child can be best palpated at?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the epigastric area: In infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the classic finding is a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region, specifically in the right upper quadrant near the midline. This mass represents the hypertrophied pylorus. It is best felt after vomiting or when the stomach is relatively empty but the child is calm, not during active feeding. The epigastric location corresponds to the anatomical position of the pylorus. Incorrect Options: A. During feeding: While symptoms like projectile non-bilious vomiting are often seen during or shortly after feeding, the abdominal mass is not best palpated during feeding, because the baby may be tense or crying, making palpation more difficult. B. In the umbilical area: This is not the typical location. The pylorus lies above and to the right of the umbilicus — specifically in the epigastric/right upper quadrant. D. In the right hypochondriac quadrant: This area is too far lateral and superior. The pyloric mass is usually more medial and in the epigastric area, not under the ribs in the hypochondriac region.

questions.text: Parotid mass which has mixed consistency is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) pleomorphic adenomas are composed of a mixture of variable histology. They contain both epithelial and myoepithelial (mesenchymal) tissues, with mixed histology. They appear encapsulated and well-circumscribed however the pseudocapsule is delicate and incomplete with microscopic extensions reaching beyond it, accounting for the high risk of recurrence when these tumors are enucleated. The gross appearance depends upon the relative proportion of epithelial elements and a stromal component which may range from myxoid to cartilage. Tumors with a prominent cartilaginous matrix have a bluish-grey opalescent appearance. Three histological types have been described: • myxoid (hypocellular): most common, highest rate of recurrence • cellular • classic

questions.text: Gas-less abdomen is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute Pancreatitis • Most commonly associated with gas-less abdomen on X-ray. • Due to paralytic ileus caused by local inflammation around the pancreas. • May also show the "colon cut-off sign" (sudden cessation of gas at the splenic flexure). A. Ulcerative colitis • Typically shows gas-filled colon, and in severe cases may show toxic megacolon (grossly distended colon filled with gas). • Not gas-less. C. Intussusception • Usually presents with target sign or crescent sign on imaging, and may have air-fluid levels or gasless abdomen distally, but not typically described as completely gas-less. D. Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) • Characteristic finding is pneumatosis intestinalis (gas in the bowel wall) or portal venous gas, not a gas-less abdomen. • In severe NEC, perforation may lead to free air, but again, not classically gas-less.

questions.text: Uvula vesicae is produced by which prostate lobe

questions.text: Parathyroid autoimplantation is done using which muscle
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The parathyroid glands were identified, resected and stored in iced saline until completion of the operation. Part of the extracted supposed parathyroid glands and the surrounding fat tissue was sent for frozen section examination to confirm being parathyroid glands and to exclude malignant invasion. Each parathyroid gland was sliced into 1–3 mm slices and three or four grafts were implanted into separated muscle pockets in the anterior forearm muscles (in brachioradialis muscle), then the muscle is closed with non absorbable sutures However in our study we preferred transplantation of the parathyroid gland in the forearm instead of the neck as this site has many advantages. First, it is easy to assess the function of the graft by assessment of PTH level of antecubital vein of the grafted limb. Secondly, most of our patients have advanced tumor and most of them are in need for postoperative adjuvant radiotherapy or have already received preoperative radiotherapy which has an adverse effect on function and vascularity of grafted parathyroid gland. Another factor is that the sternomastoid muscle may be resected with radical neck dissection during the primary surgery or surgery for treatment of nodal recurrence. For all of these reasons, we preferred to do our transplanted parathyroid gland in the forearm instead of the neck.
